title: RS22960
content: Japan's financial crisis in the late 1980s began with stock market and real estate bubbles fueled by excess liquidity. Investors and speculators took advantage of the rising market values, leading to a burst in the bubbles. The Nikkei stock market average peaked before the crisis hit. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s led to a significant drop in stock market and real estate values. Banks, which had considered loans with real estate collateral as secure, saw their capital reserves drastically reduced as the value of their stock holdings plummeted. Commercial land values in major metropolitan areas fell by 80%, while residential and industrial land values dropped by nearly 20%. This caused the value of collateral underlying many bank loans to decrease below the loan principal, making commercial real estate ventures unprofitable. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s led to a significant drop in stock market and real estate values, causing the value of collateral underlying many bank loans to drop below the loan principal. This led to a financial and banking crisis, slowing down the overall Japanese economy. Companies faced excess capacity, inventories, and lower profits as more loans turned sour and real estate had to be sold at bargain prices. Japan's banks reported $280 billion in non-performing loans in 1995, which was vastly understated. Unlike the US, Japanese financial institutions did not bundle loans as collateralized debt obligations or rely heavily on derivatives and credit default swaps. Mortgage defaults in Japan were mainly on commercial property, not private residences. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s caused a drop in stock market and real estate values, leading to a banking crisis. Japanese banks had $280 billion in non-performing loans in 1995, mainly due to commercial property defaults. Commercial lending in Japan was often relational, based on connections rather than market-based. Loans were extended based on corporate ties, leading to many loans turning sour. The adverse effects spread to the entire economy, causing economic growth rates to fall. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s led to a drop in stock market and real estate values, causing a banking crisis with $280 billion in non-performing loans by 1995. This crisis spread adverse effects to the entire economy, resulting in economic growth rates falling from over 5% in the late 1980s to less than 2% in the early 1990s. The economy saw a temporary recovery in 1996 but fell back into recession in 1998 and 1999 due to fiscal policy tightening and the Asian Financial Crisis. The recession continued into the early 2000s, leading to an extended L-shaped downturn for Japan. The bursting of Japan's stock and real estate bubbles in 1989 and 1990 led to a banking crisis. The government's initial strategy was forbearance, protecting depositors and assisting in mergers of failed institutions. The government intervened extensively to ensure the stability of the banking system. In response to the banking crisis caused by the bursting of Japan's stock and real estate bubbles in 1989 and 1990, the government implemented forbearance policies to protect depositors and facilitate mergers of failed institutions. Stronger banks supported weaker ones to prevent major bank failures, reflecting a "community banking mentality" that prioritized long-term profits over short-term gains. The government later established the Cooperative Credit Purchasing Company (CCPC) in 1992 to help banks deal with non-performing loans, similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States. The Cooperative Credit Purchasing Company (CCPC) was established in 1992 to assist banks in disposing of non-performing loans, similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States. In 1993, top banks sold ¥1.3 trillion in non-performing loans to the CCPC, accounting for 54% of all loans written off that year. The selling bank would extend credit to the CCPC for the purchase cost of the loan plus processing expenses, allowing the bank to claim a capital loss for tax purposes. The CCPC recovered about half of the underlying value of the non-performing loans through sales of the collateral. The government hoped that banks could fund write-offs of bad loans through profits from operations and capital gains. Despite billions in write-offs, nonperforming loans continued to appear. Japan's banks wrote off $318 billion in non-performing loans during the crisis. During Japan's financial crisis, banks wrote off $318 billion in non-performing loans, but new ones kept emerging, leading to a peak of $330 billion in outstanding loans by March 2002. The government implemented multiple stimulus packages between 1992 and 1995, with new spending amounting to 0.3% to 1.5% of GDP in each package. Despite initial slow recovery, the situation worsened in 1995 with the bankruptcy of housing loan companies, leading to the government's first capital injection in 1996 to aid ailing lenders. In 1996, the government injected capital to rescue ailing housing lenders, which was politically unpopular. The Japanese economy's sorry state since 1995 was attributed to weak fiscal, monetary, and supervision policies, leading to a larger problem than necessary. The economy showed signs of recovery in 1996, partly due to spending on reconstruction after the Kansai earthquake and consumer purchases of durables. In 1997, Japan's banking sector faced a systemic crisis, leading the government to provide $250 billion for financial institutions. This included $108 billion for banks and $142 billion for the Deposit Insurance Corporation. The government also acquired the bankrupt Long-Term Credit Bank and Nippon Credit Bank, eventually selling them to private investors. Additionally, the government injected $14 billion in March 1998 to strengthen bank balance sheets. The Japanese government provided financial support to the banking sector by injecting billions of dollars in March 1998 and March 1999. By October 1998, a total of $495 billion was invested, leading to a gradual recovery in the banking sector. Through various measures such as capital injections, new regulations, and economic recovery, the banks reported 3.5% of non-performing loans by September 2005. The government utilized monetary policy, direct intervention, and fiscal stimulus packages to combat the crisis. During the 1990s crisis, the Japanese government implemented monetary policy, direct intervention, and fiscal stimulus packages. Nine stimulus packages were announced, with some incorporating items from previous budgets. The government raised the consumption tax in April 1997 to reduce the fiscal deficit. New spending was referred to as "real water" (mamizu), indicating the actual funds allocated. The Japanese government referred to new spending as "real water" (mamizu) during the 1990s crisis. Stimulus packages were announced, with combined totals as a percent of GDP in certain years. Bank rescue operations were primarily administered by the Deposit Insurance Corporation of Japan (DICJ), which assisted failing financial institutions through asset purchases or mergers. The DICJ provides financial assistance to prevent financial institutions from failing, including direct money grants, loans, asset purchases, guarantees, and capital injections. It also insures bank deposits and has provided $399 billion in assistance as of March 2007. The DICJ provided financial assistance totaling $399 billion, including grants, asset purchases, and capital injections. The grants were funded by DICJ bonds and deposit insurance premiums. Asset purchases of $83 billion included recovering $79 billion. Capital injections of $106 billion were made into 25 different banks. As of March 2007, $31.3 billion of these assets was still held by the DICJ. The DICJ injected capital into 25 banks, holding $31.3 billion in assets as of March 2007. The "Other" category included loans to banks under special management, asset delivery, compensation, lending to financial institutions, and debt assumption. The last capital injection was in March 2003. The RCC, a DICJ subsidiary, purchased assets worth $34.5 billion for $3.0 billion by borrowing funds from the DICJ. The Resolution and Collection Corporation (RCC) purchased troubled assets for a discounted price and sold them at a profit, gaining 172%. Japan's government debt increased as the economy stagnated, following a pattern seen in other financial crises worldwide. Japan's central government debt as a percent of GDP doubled in the three years following a crisis, reaching 106% in 2000. The Ricardian equivalence theorem suggests that government deficits may not stimulate demand as individuals anticipate future tax increases to repay the debt. The analysis of Japan's experience in the 1990s found that Ricardian equivalence effects existed but were not significant for fiscal policy. Despite high saving rates and public awareness of rising government debt, fiscal stimulus packages had expected multiplier effects. Tax cuts targeting the most liquidity constrained had the largest effects, while fiscal stimulus was deemed necessary due to limitations on monetary stimulus. In the 1990s, Japan pursued fiscal stimulus to address economic challenges caused by limited monetary stimulus options. However, the impact of fiscal deficits on growth was muted due to insufficient efforts to address non-performing loans and economic deregulation. Japan implemented the Fiscal Structural Reform Act in 1997 to reduce government debt and deficits, but the tightening of fiscal policy may have prolonged the recession. The Japanese government aimed to reduce the deficit to GDP to 3% by 2003, but the tightening of fiscal policy occurred too soon, prolonging the recession. By 2003, the government debt-to-GDP ratio rose to 141% and the deficit to GDP ratio increased to 5.4%. Despite some economic growth from 2002-2007, the national debt continued to grow, highlighting the challenge of reducing the debt burden in a stagnant economy. The Japanese government reports two categories of expenditures for servicing the debt: Interest Paid and National Debt Service. National Debt Service includes interest paid, redemption of the national debt, and administrative expenses. Japan's interest payments as a percentage of federal government expenditures declined from 17% in the early 1990s to 11.5% in 2007, despite the growing national debt, due to a drop in interest rates as part of the government's monetary policy. The decline in Japan's interest payments as a percentage of federal government expenditures from 17% in the early 1990s to 11.5% in 2007 was due to a drop in interest rates as part of the government's monetary policy. The United States also saw a decrease in the share of interest in outlays from around 15% in the 1990s to 8.3% in 2008. The question for both nations is whether this trend can continue given the large fiscal deficits being incurred in 2009. Observers have gleaned various lessons from the Japanese experience, including underestimating the seriousness of the banking problem initially. Authorities in Japan initially underestimated the severity of the banking problem, hoping economic growth and low interest rates would resolve it. The extent of non-performing loans and support for "zombie" firms delayed a solution. Transparency in reporting non-performing loans was crucial. Government capital injections were often needed to rescue struggling financial institutions. A lack of decisive action earlier was attributed to a lack of constraints and political leadership. The Japanese government created new institutions to handle emergency financial assistance and later transferred these activities to the Deposit Insurance Corporation of Japan (DICJ). The DICJ was given permanent authority to assist ailing financial institutions when ordered by the Prime Minister, injecting capital in various ways and disposing of troubled assets at a discount without disrupting markets. The Japanese government injected capital into ailing financial institutions by buying discounted assets and later selling them to private investors. Between 1998 and 2003, Japan's banks wrote off $318 billion in non-performing loans despite receiving $495 billion in financial support packages. The government's holdings of corporate shares generated income for the DICJ. Recovery efforts were focused on a smaller number of banks and financial institutions compared to the United States. Japan placed stringent conditions on financial assistance packages. Japan's financial rescue package had stringent conditions that banks refused, leading them to avoid lending and worsen economic conditions. Assistance to failing institutions had enforced conditions by the DICJ. The bursting of the real estate bubble in Japan impacted banks more than the stock market bubble burst. Japan's slow response to monetary actions exacerbated the situation. The bursting of the real estate bubble in Japan had a significant impact on banks due to the decline in real estate values affecting collateral on bank lending. Japan's slow response to monetary and fiscal policies, as well as delays in resolving banking sector issues, worsened the situation. Fiscal policy was believed to have tightened prematurely after the economy began to recover.
